resources.string: Please provide the host name or IP address of the machine which has rotctld running.
Please provide the port number of the rotctld process.

This GUI application works with the open source hamlib project. ( http://hamlib.sourceforge.net )
 You need a rotor that can be controlled via serial port and a computer that is connected to that rotor controller via the serial port. This computer must also be connected to the local area network and running the hamlib rotctld rotor control daemon. The rotor must support the get_position and set_position commands. This app connects via the network to that daemon (usually on port 4533), and sends and gets the heading. At present, it works for azimuth only. 
For setup information on the server, see the man page. It is available at ( http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/lucid/man8/rotctld.8.html ). 
 Once you have the rotctld running on the server you start this app on your phone and hit the "Connect to Server" button. It will disappear, and you will have the option of getting the present heading of the rotor (in degrees) with the "Get Heading" button or setting a new heading with the "Heading" text entry field. The rotor will rotate to the new heading (which is apporoximately what you asked for in the text field by typing in a bearing in degrees). A CDE or HyGain rotor generally turns at about one revolution per minute, but to get closer to your specified heading, the rotor will seek with some controllers (like the Heathkit Intellirotor) for a while longer. You will know it is finished when you get a new heading on the screen. If you wish you can quit this app soon after setting the new heading, and the rotation will still complete.
